WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name MRS. G. M. DAWENT
Address M.A.T.R.O.U.S., SASK.
Birthplace DULLEY, STAFFORDSHIRE ENGLAND

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? W.M. 22, Range 24, Township 31, West 2nd
Where had you been living before that? Invercote, Waterloo Farm 2 years
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3. Husband, Self, Boy aged
How far was it to your nearest store? 5.0 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? 2 times in 6 months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, rolled oats, sugar, tea, yeast, syrup, lard

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? First years
I do not remember what brand rolled oats
In what quantities did you buy it? Nov. 15, 1906, 6 bags, 7 lbs., 50 lb. rolled oats
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? I don't remember
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No, how far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? I don't remember
What other grain products did you use? Corn meal
Corn meal? None, Whole wheat? None, Farina? None
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
MRS. A. M. DARWENT
Atreton Matron, O.M.
Matron, 1926

PUDLEY, STAFFORDSHIRE, ENGLAND

1. PERSONAL HISTORY

What year did you enter nursing school? 1906
Where did you go to nursing school? St. Mary's Hospital School of Nursing
How long have you been working in this hospital? Since 1906
Have you ever worked in another hospital? No
How many years have you been working here? 30
What was your first position? Head Nurse
What is your current position? Matron

2. FOOD AND DIETARY PRODUCTS

What brand of milk do you use in the hospital? S.W.A.
In what quantities do you buy? 100 lbs.
What is the usual price per hundred pounds of milk? $1.50
How much milk do you use each day? 100 lbs.
What kind of flour do you use? Whole wheat flour
Was flour milled locally? Yes
Was flour milled by yourself? No
What was the price for a twenty-pound bag of flour? $1.50
Did you purchase any other food products? No
What were they? None
Did you make your own bread? No
How did you make it? By hand
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lb. sack.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 50 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Sugar.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? I do not remember.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had our own cows.

Butter? Made my own.

Eggs? Own eggs.

What was the price of butter? 10 cents.

Did you pack eggs for market? No.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Wild ducks in summer.

How did you get fresh meat? Did not have any.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? We dry salted pork.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not till 1923.

If so what year was it organized? 1923.

Did you use game? Wild ducks.

What kinds? Prairie chickens.

For how long? I don't remember.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We never had any.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds?
3. **SUGAR AND STARCH**
   
   In what quantity did you buy sugar last week? 10 lbs.
   
   That was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 5¢ per pound.

   What brand of molasses syrup did you use? Progess.

   What color of this or syrup did you usually buy? Dark brown.

   At what price? 1¢ per lb.

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**

   How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had cows and butter.

   What was the price of butter? 16¢ per lb.

   Did you pack eggs for market? No.

   Did you make butter? Yes.

   What kind of cheese?

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

   What was your meat supply in the early years? Wild game.

   How did you get fresh meat? We bought small hogs and cattle.

   Was there a butcher in your neighborhood? Yes.

   If so, what year was it established? 1923.

   Did you use game? Yes.

   For how long? I don't remember.

   What part did fish play in the family diet? We never had any.

   Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

   Kind?
6. Beverages

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? $1.00 per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Did not use coffee.

Price? ................. What other beverages were used? .......................

7. Vegetables and Dried Fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? Didn't buy. Could you get potatoes at the store? Didn't know.

If not, where from? ..............................................................

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1907. Cabbage .......... Carrots .......... Onions .............

Turnips .......... Beets .......... 

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 4 lb.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.

What weight? 5 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...

By Date. What was the price of prunes? Didn't know.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. Preserving

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? No. Corn? No. Beans? No. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods? ..................................................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? I don't remember.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ...................

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ....................

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

To what extent? ..................................................................

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

In 1906 and 1907 I gathered mushrooms and wild strawberries, just enough to make a meal. They were not very plentiful.
6. What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. Are they privately shipped? Yes. Best kind of source did you buy? (Brand or brand). What part of the state? (Not sure).

7. Vegetables and Fruits Purchased. Did you get potatoes at the store? I don't know. If yes, where from? I don't know. Did you first grow your own supply for the winter or buy? Potatoes 12.47. Turnips 8.25. Cabbage 5.89. In what quantities did you buy? 5 lbs. How much did you pay per lb.? 5 lbs.

8. Following. In the early years did you preserve any foods by freezing? Yes, beans, corn, etc. Other foods? No. That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? I don't remember. That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? That year did you first preserve meat by canning? Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

In 1906 and 1907 I gathered mushrooms and wild strawberries just enough to make a meal. Why was not very plentiful.

12. WATER SUPPLY Hole dug beside a slough

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Dug well 1907. Melted Slough ice in winter
Have since dug 3 wells on Homestead.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your house? .................................................. 5.0 yards

Was it brought to the house? (well, barrel, tank) ........................................... Pail.

Has there been any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading? (river, dugout, well)

Buy well 1907. Halted through ice in winter

Have since Aug 3 well on Homestead.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Royal Brown.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes. Wood ashes? No.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? I don't know.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From Baxter in Brandon Lake.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Coal got it from lumber yards.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Mrs. Clark.

That year was it purchased? 1926. Second hand? Yes.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, copper, tin.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware, bought in Manitoba.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1910.

Aluminum? I don't remember.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Sold butter in cellophane 1906.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1906. For days at a time would be rolled oats porridge, bread, Butter and Tea 3 times a day.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Christmas 1906... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

A pudding made with flour, syrup, Baking Powder
We got a little Beef from a neighbor, and potatoes

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No. But I was without flour for 2 weeks. My husband had to go to Hanley 50 miles for our supplies. He bought 6 bags flour rolls rolled oats 2 20 lbs pails syrup and 50 lb pail hard on Nov 15th 1906. But by the end of the winter it was all gone.

We had deep snow, and only ocean, so could not go to Hanley till May. The reason I do not know. Price my Husband did the buying, and he has passed away.

Have answered question to the best of my ability.
Fold butter in March 1906.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the numbers of the family members at the table. Make up the approximate number of each food item served.

18. Tell how you made your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada. What did you serve? Give the menu. List those present and five other guests at the time.

19. In 1906, for days at a time would be rolled oats, hominy, bread, butter and tea. 3 times a day

20. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation levels living on one or two local products? Details?

21. But I was without flour for 9 weeks. My husband had to go to Hamilton 50 miles for our supplies. He bought 6 bags flour rolls rolled out 2. 20 lbs flour and 50 lbs hail hard on Mar 15th 1906. But by the end of the winter it was all gone. We had deep snow, and only now, so could not go to Hanly Hill. The reason I do not know. But my husband died the following and he was buried away.

Have answered question to the best of my ability.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

"When I first sold butter in Watrous it was unwrapped, I do remember when the wrapper came in but it is a great improvement."
When I first sold butter in Kalpine
it was unsupplied, I do remember
when the supplies came in but it is a
great improvement
My second son was born Dec 14th 1906. My nearest neighbor was 2 miles away, if near at home in the town of Hanley 50 miles away. My son and his family live on the homestead he was born on.
My second son was born Dec 4th 1906. My nearest neighbor was 2 miles away. Nearest doctor in the town of Hanley 50 miles away. My son and his family live on the homestead he was born on.
